results.title: The Great escape
results.creator_credit: Allen Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: “That day the Americans gave us a fruit cake was a very rare day indeed, as breaks were not on the cards”. A near-miss while relaxing in Tambu Bay, New Guinea right near the end of the war was a turning point in more ways than one. The senselessness of war drove Allen to find his own happiness and sense of meaning when he returned to civilian life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Great Egyptians
results.brief_description:
The true life stories of six of the great kings and queens of ancient Egypt- Part One: The Mystery of Tutankhamen; Who was the boy king? In 1923, his tomb was found by Howard Carter intact, but to this day, we are still uncertain of his lineage.
Part Two: The Real Cleopatra; Cleopatra has often been portrayed as cruel and promiscuous. Evidence now indicates she was a monogamous woman, a devoted mother, and a compassionate queen to her people.
Part Three: King of the Pyramids; The Pharoah Sneferu showed the Egyptians how to construct pyramids and with his genius and determination established Egypt as an international power.
Part Four: Ramses the Great; Ramses II built on a scale unequalled by any ruler in history, bragged about his military prowess, and was fond of listing the names of his two hundred children.
Part Five: The Queen Who Would Be King; Hatsheput wanted to be king, not queen; and she succeeded. Pushing aside her nephew and rightful heir to the throne, Tuthmoses III, she ruled as king of upper and lower Egypt for twenty two years.
Part Six: The Rebel Pharoah; At the end of the eighteenth dynasty the pharoah Amenhotep IV changed his name to Akhenaten and declared there is but one god, Aten the solar disk. Presented by Bob Brier.

results.title: The Great director
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
The second of a trilogy throwing new light on Chaplin’s career in films. In 1917 he became independent and built his own studio. Stills, camera tests and rushes are organised to produce new insights into his famous classics, “The Kid”, “The Gold Rush” and “City Lights”. Narrated by James Mason. Rated: G

results.title: The great dinosaur hunt
results.creator_credit: Brian Beaton, Location Equipment and Reel Images
results.brief_description: Western Australia is one of the oldest areas in the world and contains the earliest fossilised evidence of life walking on earth. This video follows Australian palaeontologist, Dr John Long, and the Dinosaur Club of the Museum of Western Australia (which includes hundreds of children) on their hunt for fossils, bones and footprints of the dinosaurs who once lived in that state. Computer and model animation are used to illustrate the dinosaurs whose relics have been unearthed, some of which are unknown in the Northern Hemisphere, which possibly suggests Australia was the last home of the dinosaurs before their extinction.

results.title: The Great dictator
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin and Charles Chaplin Productions
results.brief_description: Chaplin plays dual roles in what was his first dialogue film: a burlesque of Hitler alias Adenoid Hynkel, and a Jewish barber who returns an amnesiac many years after an accident in World War I, unaware of the rise of Nazism. The parody of Hitler draws not only on Chaplin’s genius for mime but also on his vocal resources. His most experimental work, the film was politically audacious for the times receiving a mixed reception in an America in the grip of isolationism but an enthusiastic one in blitzed London. Cast includes Paulette Goddard, Jack Oakie and Reginald Gardiner.

results.title: The Great diamond
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Math that counts”.
Repeated division is visualized several times in this humorous animated film. The Drok tribe attempt to smuggle the Great Diamond out of their castle by breaking it into four hundred and eighty-seven pieces. They put sixteen pieces into their boot heels - but how many boots will be needed in all?

results.creator_credit: Sonya Friedman, Henriette Montgomery and Texture Films
results.brief_description: Uses live action and animation to present observations about dress, including its significance as a means of self-expression, its role as part of the total design of an age, and the way in which it reflects prevailing political and social issues.

results.title: The Great commanders
results.creator_credit: Phil Grabsky and Seventh Art Productions
results.brief_description: A six part series which looks at six individuals considered to be military giants. Their motivation and the qualities which made them great commanders are analysed by experts. 3D computer animation is used to illustrate each commander’s particular skill in battle. Each program takes as its focus a key battle which examines the nature of each individual’s military command.
